comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Puzzlingly, the NYT select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30716FD345E1673... of June 18, 1933 reports the 10 millionth passenger on North German Lloyd. That would be way out of chronological sequence.

comment.author: 37430507@N03
comment._content: the plastic life rescue thing states "Bremen". maybe one could conclude this picture is taken there, since it was the 10th millionth passenger, they probrably made a fuzz about it in their homeharbour?

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The lifebelt says George Washington, Bremen. It probably comes from the SS George Washington, which sailed between Bremen and New York frequently during this period and whose port of registry was Bremen. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_George_Washington_(1908) This ship was seized by the US during WWI and would not have been a North German Lloyd vessel in 1933.
